messages.text:
Where to begin?
1. <@U66SGEWAC> saved my ass (again), helping me fix a bunch of issues I had with plotting and serving things off of a Raspberry Pi. 
2. I installed Julia 1.3.1 (cause that's what can run on Raspbian 32bit) on that RPI and everything just worked! I think I missed the new named-tuple thing `(; this, thing)`, like once. Other than that, everything literally just worked!
3. People here are so eager to help, it's just so nice. Also, it's the only way I can get so much done. 
So thank you all for everything!!!

elements.text: Where to begin?
saved my ass (again), helping me fix a bunch of issues I had with plotting and serving things off of a Raspberry Pi.
I installed Julia 1.3.1 (cause that's what can run on Raspbian 32bit) on that RPI and everything just worked! I think I missed the new named-tuple thing
(; this, thing)
, like once. Other than that, everything literally just worked!
People here are so eager to help, it's just so nice. Also, it's the only way I can get so much done.
So thank you all for everything!!!

messages.text: <@U681ELA87> and all the other contributors who made Arrow.jl an official Apache project. Bringing zero copy data transfers to the language!

elements.text: and all the other contributors who made Arrow.jl an official Apache project. Bringing zero copy data transfers to the language!

messages.text: I am also grateful for Arrow.jl and <@U681ELA87>’s work on it, but I would like to point out that there was already plenty of zero copy data transfers all over Julia, because the language does not suffer from the limitations of the language(s) (one language very much in particular) that arrow was originally designed to overcome  (though, of course, now we can enjoy zero-copy with all the other stuff that works with arrow, which we certainly did not have before)

messages.text: Moderna's Covid vaccine: made possible by Pumas and Julia!!!

messages.text: A few days ago, I was getting frustrated with the complexity of metaprogramming. Today I'm parsing through Python code that `evals` itself into existence, and I have a new appreciation of metaprogramming. I have been enlightened.

messages.text:
Thanks everyone for helping out this year! I immensely appreciate this community! :heart: 
Hope the world around us gets better next year and the community stays the same being open and awesome!
 (For some already this year. How is 2021 so far?)

elements.text: Thanks everyone for helping out this year! I immensely appreciate this community!

 (For some already this year. How is 2021 so far?)

messages.text: Although we live in the US, we celebrated with the New Year’s tradition in Spain, eating 12 grapes, one every time the bell tolls in the Puerto del Sol in Madrid (watching like Spaniards all over Spain and the world on TV or internet stream)

messages.text: writing julia code is just _so fulfilling_ sometimes. I had prepared a branch in a project to implement a corner case for one of my algorithms, but after trying it I realized that my upstream code was generic enough to Just Work^TM. I appreciate all the effort that goes into the language that enables that little *magic* feeling. It’s truly energizing and gives me so much motivation to create more and do more.

elements.text: writing julia code is just
so fulfilling

sometimes. I had prepared a branch in a project to implement a corner case for one of my algorithms, but after trying it I realized that my upstream code was generic enough to Just Work^TM. I appreciate all the effort that goes into the language that enables that little *magic* feeling. It’s truly energizing and gives me so much motivation to create more and do more.

messages.text: I know this has been said before, but LoopVectorization is simply incredible. Just put a bunch of `@avx` macros in front of loops and, boom, a factor of >5 speedup. (<https://stackoverflow.com/questions/65542598/integration-of-interaction-tensor>) :tada: :mind_blown:

messages.text: You know you are in for a wonderful treat when you ask a question and someone immediately says something to the effect of, "let's play with it some!" and invites you in to see the action. Big thanks to <@USU9FRPEU> and <@U6788D83U> for explaining some maths and for a visual proof from <@UB197FRCL>. I really enjoy the community we have and our general feel about encouraging folks to ask questions. :hugging_face:

messages.text: This blog is very helpful! <https://www.maximiliankoehler.de/posts/pluto-server/>

attachments.title: How To: Set Up a Pluto.jl Server for Teaching Purposes
attachments.text: I want to share what my colleague Dennis Ogiermann and me learnt while setting up a server that I’m going to use for a teaching adventure with Julia. I’ll teach exercises in the course “Basics of FEM” for mechanical engineers. The problems The mechanical engineering students have no or little experience with programming (and very likely no experience with a terminal) There is no time to teach them in depth programming, terminal handling, etc.
attachments.fallback: How To: Set Up a Pluto.jl Server for Teaching Purposes

elements.text: This blog is very helpful!

messages.text: Shout out to <@UDD5Z7FLZ> for winning the one liner of the 8 months award: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/fun-one-liners/28352/130>

attachments.title: Fun One Liners
attachments.text: I just had this fun one liner. Let say you wish to do polynomial interpolation given an array v and f.(v) == w, you wish to find f(x). ([y^i for y in v, i in 0:length(v)] \ w)'*[x^i for i in 0:length(v)-1]

messages.text: I've been holding off of trying out 1.6 because I wanted to wait for a beta release, but I couldn't stop myself and built it locally (and because it seems closeish now) - and wowzers, was it worth it! There are so many pretty colors in `@code_llvm` and `@code_native` now, precompilation is :gotta-go-fast:  and all in all it feels really snappy and fast. Much :heart:  to everyone who contributed!
